As a result of that, they put on the table as a -- as end state that you must announce to complete withdrawal for the United States. So, I think that's coming, if the president goes along with the proposal, I hope he does not.

And that proposal will say that the United States would likely withdraw our all troops by the end of 2020. And as a result of that, there is a couple of conditions. One, the Taliban will negotiate with the Afghan government. That's a good thing.

Two, and listen to this closely, the Taliban will guaranty that the al- Qaeda will not reconstitute a safe haven in Afghanistan which is a reason why we're there, in the first place, because that's from where the attack on 9/11 came, and they will also destroy ISIS.

What's wrong with that? One is we are trusting the Taliban.

BARTIROMO: Well, right. I was going to say, should we believe them?

KEANE: Does anybody believe that the al-Qaeda is not talking to the -- that the Taliban is not talking to the al-Qaeda right now, and saying to them, lie low. The Americans are going to get out by the end of 2020. Don't increase your fighters, don't increase any of your activity. When they walk out the door, you can come back here and do what you want to do.

BARTIROMO: Do you think the president is going to listen to the sentiment that they are doing it?

KEANE: I hope the president is going through a consideration of what to do. And I just hope he is listening.

BARTIROMO: Yes, very similar comments that you make as Senator Lindsey Graham on Sunday. General, it's great to see you.

KEANE: Yes, great talking to you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. General Jack Keane, there.

Meanwhile, Dale Earnhardt Jr. breaking his silence, days after he and his family survived a fiery plane crash.

Cheryl Casone with the headlines, now. Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria. Dale Earnhardt Jr. released a statement on Twitter. And he thanked supporters, and he also said his family is truly blessed that all on board escaped that crash with no serious injuries.

The private jet rolled off runway in east Tennessee and caught fire after landing last week. Earnhardt and his family spent a few hours at a hospital before being released.

Earnhardt's wife sharing the sweet photo saying, "God is good." That, of course, is their baby in that picture.

General Electric is now firing back against accusations by Harry Markopolos. The company has told investors that the current reserves for its long-term care insurance business are well funded.

G.E. also defended the accounting for its oil and gas business. Last Thursday, Markopolos accused G.E. of filing inaccurate or fraudulent regulation with regulators, sending the shares down about 11 percent.

G.E. chief executive Larry Culp, said the allegations from the Bernie Madoff whistleblower are mounted to market manipulation. Stay tuned on that one.

And then, there is this. Another whistleblower claiming that Disney inflated revenue for years. Sandra Kuba, a former accountant at Disney, says the company over sent an annual revenue by as much as $6 billion.

Kuba filed a number of complaints with the SEC. Disney who fired Kuba back in 2017, said it looked into her claims and found them to be, "utterly baseless".

And Maria, I love this one. Recall that ladies night at the Country Music Awards is so fun, right? Carrie Underwood teaming up with Reba McEntire and -- oh my gosh, Dolly Parton. The host country's biggest night.

The powerhouse lad that means that Brad Paisley has been hosting the show with Underwood since 2008, out of a gig, but it seemed OK, with the switchers when he tweeted.

As a fan of all three of these amazing women, I can't wait to watch. The CMA broadcast November 13th, nominees announced, Maria, next week. Dolly Parton, she is back.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's good news. I will watch it though, and Cheryl, thank you so much.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: I will be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headline as cross America this morning. The San Francisco Chronicle reports: "Bay Area cities are poised to follow Berkeley's natural gas ban." Now, with Berkeley leading the way as the first U.S. city to ban national gas lines in new residential buildings, San Jose, Santa Rosa and Petaluma are ready to follow in order to meet climate goals, heating and appliances like dryers and ranges would have to run on electricity.

The Chicago Tribune this morning writes: "Uber confirms it's moving to massive space in the old post office." And amass of amount of space for thousands of employees, Uber is ready to move into Chicago's old post office, signing a 10-year lease. The company says it will be the building's largest tenants, occupying 463,000 square feet.

The South Florida Sun Sentinel this morning reports: "Beat and tweet, Florida has the most complaining drivers on Twitter, study says." Autowise.com ranking Florida the "official home of the horrible driver." The site geotags Twitter data from last month and had researchers figure out what states had most mentions and complaints about bad driving. About 10,000 tweets were tracked: Virginia, Tennessee, Wisconsin and Maine rounded up top five. Is that true, Jonas?

JONAS FERRIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: It's not a qualitative analysis. If you get quotes for a car insurance across the country, you will find it. Especially Miami-Dade is about double of New York City in many occasions, there's a reason for that.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

FERRIS: (INAUDIBLE) shaken you down, that's what the settlements are.

BARTIROMO: Bottom line.

FERRIS: Between the results during the driving, that's the problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's not good. Coming up, anti-trust crack-down, states reportedly ready to move forward with big-tech investigation. Plus, whiskey business; how tariffs are affecting profits there. We are talking to one distiller up next back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, the U.S. whiskey industry struggling to make up for loss business. According to Distilled (INAUDIBLE) Council, 63 percent of American whiskey exports to face tariffs from Europe, China and others. Joining us right now is the Founder and Master Distiller of Dad's Hat Pennsylvania Rye Whiskey Company, Herman Mihalich. Herman, good to see you, thank you so much for being here this morning.

HERMAN MIHALICH, FOUNDER, DAD'S HAT PENNSYLVANIA RYE WHISKEY COMPANY: Good morning, thanks for inviting me.

BARTIROMO: So, tell us about the impact tariffs have had on your business?

MIHALICH: Well, in 2014, we were approached by importer in Europe, La Maison du Whiskey, to start exporting our products to Europe sow some nice growth, there's an umbrella created by the high scotch prices and there's also demand created by the trend of -- specialty cocktails growing in Europe as it's grown in the United States. So, we saw some nice growth in 2014 to 2017 and first and second quarter of last year, our sales dried up entirely and after talking with our importer, it was a clear loss of enthusiasm on their part to try to support pushing through that 25 percent tariff increase and we've really just lost complete sales there since second quarter of last year.

BARTIROMO: Wow, and that sounds like it's solid because of the tariffs?

MIHALICH: It really has been a widespread across other distillers as well and it just, you know, we had a window there where we were growing quite nicely and they were very enthusiastic about supporting our business, and unfortunately, that really -- you know, from a psychological point of view as well as reality on the ground of the 25 percent increase, just made it more difficult for us to get the enthusiasm we need to -- we need on the ground with our distributors in Europe.

MALIK: Hi, Herman, this is Omeed. I'm curious, one of the things President Trump is talking about outside of the tariffs with the European Union is he's trying to strike a bilateral trade deal with the United Kingdom. If that deal does go into place, will that help mitigate some your current struggles?

MIHALICH: Well, that's all going to depend on Brexit, right now everybody is in standstill in the U.K., you can't talk to anybody about anything, they are all sitting around waiting to see what happens. So, it's hard for me to say. Until we see what happens with Brexit, it's really a wild card.

FERRIS: Herman, how much of this -- as you said, they're still drinking -- it's still trendy to drink (INAUDIBLE) in Europe as it is here with the (INAUDIBLE) culture. How much was your tariffs and -- I believe Japanese whiskey tariffs went down recently, with deals with the E.U. where they go no tariffs now. So, what if there's dropdown? It's like what's the net tariff difference between you and the competition in Japan?

MIHALICH: That's a good question. I don't know the answer to that question, unfortunately. We don't see Japanese whiskey as district competitor necessarily because that's more of a sipping whiskey and a different culture. The target we were going after, really, was the American whiskey culture with cocktails and classic cocktails and pre- prohibition speak-easy-style cocktails.

BEVAN: Herman, this is Tom Bevan, you were also hit by tariffs in Canada and Mexico and I wonder, would a renegotiating USMCA be helpful to your business as well?

MIHALICH: Well, the changes in Canada has already sparked some interest where we had lost business in Canada as well, we've just started negotiations with an importer there to reenter the Canadian market. We've never been active in Asia; we've only been focusing on Europe for the time being. We're a fairly small company and it's difficult to spread ourselves to thinly across different markets.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Herman, we'll be watching. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

MIHALICH: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Herman Mihalich there. Still ahead, retails in focus this morning. As we told you earlier, Home Depot lowering its full-year guidance for sales. Kohl's is set to report moments from now. We'll have all those numbers as soon as they are out, next up. And then, chicken wars; feathers fighting online. The fight over who has the best chicken sandwich heats up, next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:60M5-FV91-DY66-500H-00000-00Home entertainment subscriptions soar2020-08-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:14ZLexisNexisHome entertainment subscriptions soar

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

David Swan, Chris Griffith

Hello and welcome to The Download, The Australian's technology blog for the latest tech news.

4.20pm: Home entertainment subscriptions soar

Subscriptions for streaming video, music and games have soared in Australia, according to the latest report by Telsyte.

The report says Australians took out 5.6 million new subscriptions in the six months to the end of June 2020, an increase of 18 per cent from a year ago.

Telsyte's Australian Entertainment Subscriptions Study 2020 found total subscriptions reached almost 37 million and is forecast to grow to 58 million by 2024. Streaming video on demand (SVOD) and streaming music were the two largest categories, with 16 million and 12 million subscriptions respectively.

More than half those watching video services believed they had become essential during the pandemic. Telsyte says the total number of subscriptions reached around 16.3 million at the end of June, a year-on-year increase of 32 per cent from 12.3 million in June 2019.

Netflix (5.4 million) and Stan (2.1 million) remained the top two SVOD service providers at the end of June. Amazon Prime Video and Disney+ (launched in Nov 2019) both emerged strongly with 1.7 and 1.1 million subscriptions, respectively.

Telsyte estimates that the total sports SVOD category grew by 11 per cent year on year to 4.9 million subscriptions at the end of June. Telstra Sports Live Passes, Optus Sport and Kayo Sports made up around 95 per cent of total sports SVOD subscriptions.

"Despite a hiccup during the shutdown period, sports video subscriptions are set to continue to grow strongly as fans turn to apps instead of attending stadiums," says Telsyte managing director, Foad Fadaghi.

The problem of diminished fresh content is likely to surface in the second half, with research showing consumers are recognising new program additions are in decline.

Broadcasting Video on Demand services (BVOD), including 9Now and ABC iView have benefited as Australians searched for more content during the lockdown, while the pay TV market (which includes residential cable, satellite and IPTV) is down 6 per cent year-on-year to 2.6 million subscriptions at the end of June.

Telsyte says about half of Australian households have a gaming console and five million people regularly purchase games (downloads and physical) making it a vibrant part of the entertainment market.

9.40am: The pace quickens in Huawei extradition case

Evidence used by the US to justify the extradition of Huawei Technologies chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou is "unreliable and defective" and should not be considered by a Canadian court, Meng's lawyers argued in documents released to the media.

Meng, 48, was arrested in December 2018 on a warrant from the US which alleges that she misled the bank HSBC about Huawei's business dealings in Iran. She has said she is innocent and is fighting extradition while on house arrest in Vancouver.

Meng's lawyers submitted testimony from expert witnesses including John Bellinger, a former White House lawyer, as well as a Huawei Technologies presentation outlining its relationship with businesses operating in Iran, to back Huawei's argument that the US left out key facts about communication with HSBC about Huawei's operations in Iran when requesting Meng's extradition from Canada.

The submissions show that the evidence used by the US as part of its case is "manifestly unreliable - so unreliable and defective - to justify refusing to commit (Meng) for extradition," lawyers for Huawei wrote.

The issue is scheduled to be argued in a British Columbia courtroom in September as part of Meng's extradition hearing. The entire extradition hearing is expected to run till April 2021.

On Monday, Meng will attend hearings in a Canadian courtroom via telephone, arguing for the Canadian attorney general to release more confidential documents relating to her arrest to show that her rights were abused. The Canadian attorney general has held back some of the documents related to her arrest claiming privilege.

Reuters

9.20am: Facebook lashes Apple over commission fees

Facebook says Apple has declined its request to waive a 30pc commission fee the iPhone maker charges apps listed on iOS devices, taking a shot at its fellow Big Tech peer as developers challenge the policy.

The move is the latest salvo in a long-running cold war between two of the world's most powerful tech companies, which have clashed over their approaches to user privacy as both face regulatory scrutiny over alleged anticompetitive behaviour.

Facebook said it requested the waiver so that small businesses would not have to pay Apple's cut for a new paid online events product the world's biggest social media company is launching on its core platform.

Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

On Thursday, Apple removed popular video game "Fortnite" from its app store for violating its in-app payment guidelines, sparking a backlash online and prompting developer Epic Games to file a federal antitrust lawsuit challenging Apple's rules.

Apple takes a cut of between 15pc and 30pc for most app subscriptions and payments made inside apps, though there are some exceptions for companies that already have a credit card on file for iPhone customers if they also offer an in-app payment that would benefit Apple.

Reuters

value.Title: Homegrown ideas need our support
value.Overview: The Toronto Star, BUSINESS; Pg. B2, 685words

Extracts.SummaryText: ... regulation). But the issue persists. While taxes and regulatory policies are important, they're too often an excuse to drive dividends and stock buybacks and line investors' pockets. For greater effect, they should be designed to incentivize adoption of transformative technologies - especially technologies that Canada can leverage to compete on the global stage. Like clean tech. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XYD-FFY1-DY91-K3RW-00000-00Homegrown ideas need our support2020-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B2Homegrown ideas need our supportYung Wu Contributor

A new year, a new decade for the Canadian economy. But what is Canada's advantage for the 2020s?

We're not going to undercut the global heavyweights on taxes or labour costs. To win this race, we have to place strategic bets on a few important horses.

Fortunately, we're already running ahead in a lane with critical global significance: clean tech. I don't know of any other country doing a volume of smarter, more innovative work in this space.

But if Canadian innovators have the tech, why aren't they already leading this race? Why are commercialization and scale such chronic problems for our startups?

Here's one big reason: Their home market isn't adopting enough of their transformative solutions. The problem isn't supply, it's demand. Demand from consumers in some cases, but also demand from Canadian business leaders, who have the capital but simply aren't as supportive of homegrown technology solutions as they are in other countries.

For years, economists, analysts and journalists fretted over Canada's competitiveness problem. They cite the same old causes (history, culture) and offer the same old policy solutions (lower taxes, less regulation). But the issue persists.

While taxes and regulatory policies are important, they're too often an excuse to drive dividends and stock buybacks and line investors' pockets.

For greater effect, they should be designed to incentivize adoption of transformative technologies - especially technologies that Canada can leverage to compete on the global stage. Like clean tech.

We often talk about commercialization like it's a nut for startups to crack before profiting. But lack of adoption also hurts the big companies, because they're missing out on competitive advantage. This isn't charity - it's fiduciary duty.

Our competitors understand what's at stake. Look at how Germany, South Korea and the United States support their homegrown companies. Look at China, which is speed-running the adoption race at giant scale. Alibaba has 550 million shoppers. Didi, which bought out Uber's China operation, has 20 million drivers in 400 cities. That's what "all in" innovation adoption looks like.

Back to clean tech. One important lane for Canada is energy storage. Our country sells surplus energy too cheaply and buys peak energy too dearly. Our inability to use renewables efficiently has kept us pumping out carbon too long. We need energy storage solutions.

Fortunately, we have companies like Hydrostor, which pumps compressed air into underwater balloons at off-peak times, then releases it to run generators when the grid needs power. They did a much-publicized pilot off the Toronto Islands, but had to go to Australia to see the technology adopted at scale. That project in a flooded mine will seek electricity directly into Australia's national grid.

Here in Canada, it took fellow innovation NRSTOR to partner with them to launch a commercial scale rollout in Goderich, Ont.

And China? It's in the middle of a five-year plan to invest almost $500 billion in renewables. Are we waiting for the next wave of commercially viable energy storage companies to happen there? That could work out. Or we could get another Huawei. Why not buy the solutions being developed at home?

The big tech story of 2019 was venture capital froth. But the investments that really matter to most companies are when people and businesses buy their products.

In the decade ahead, Canadian businesses need to keep their eye on the products emerging in their own back yard. Competitive advantage means spending on transformational tech before someone else does.

If a Canadian company's not in a position to do it today, it can help by championing smart policy that will make it easier to do so.

For instance, innovation-friendly policies like flow-through shares, which spurred investment in Canada's resource sector decades ago.

What resources were to the old economy, innovation is to the new one. Picking lanes, strategic bets, adopting transformative homegrown technologies for competitive advantage - that's Canada's advantage for the 2020s.

Yung Wu is CEO of MaRs Discovery District.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VJN-8VG1-F19Y-C4RJ-00000-00Hong Kong boosts innovation, tech fund to reduce reliance on service industries2019-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisExtraHong Kong boosts innovation, tech fund to reduce reliance on service industriesXiuxi Zhu

Hong Kong plans to bolster its technology and innovation investments and leverage China's Greater Bay Area plan, the city's Financial Secretary Paul Chan said in a 2019-2020 budget speech.

Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan, said during a 2019-2020 budget speech on Feb. 27, the city plans to bolster its innovation and technology investments to "help reduce [the] economy's over-reliance on service industries."

Chan said Hong Kong will inject HK$2 billion into its innovation and technology fund to launch a re-industrialization funding scheme which subsidizes manufacturers and helps them set up in Hong Kong. The innovation and technology fund was first established in 1999 to help upgrade the innovation and technology used in Hong Kong's manufacturing and service industries.

The city will also set up a HK$2 billion innovation and technology venture fund to co-invest in local startups with venture capital funds. "We selected a total of six co-investment partners in mid-2018, and have been receiving co-investment proposals, Chan said.

The financial secretary added the government will develop the city's technology infrastructures allocating an additional of HK$2 billion to Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corp., on top of last year s HK$3 billion. Further, the government will inject HK$5.5 billion to develop Hong Kong's innovation area, called Cyberport, where big tech companies including Microsoft Corp. sit.

The budget speech also mentioned capitalizing on opportunities that will be presented by the "Greater Bay Area," or GBA, plan. First announced by Premier Li Keqiang in 2017 and detailed further Feb. 18, the initiative is China's push for technology supremacy, linking a cluster of Chinese cities, including Shenzhen and Guangzhou, with the autonomous regions of Hong Kong and Macau.

Hong Kong will spend some HK$110 million to set up offices in the GBA, Chan said during a press conference on the same day of his speech. He added Hong Kong will have to overcome difficulties, such as the complication of a three-customs system. Analysts and experts believe the initiative may straddle Hong Kong-based technology, media and telecom companies due to regulatory differences.

urn:contentItem:605C-HHY1-JCMN-Y2N2-00000-00Hong Kong Disneyland reopens, consumers using less cash2020-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:14ZLexisNexisHong KongDisneyland reopens, consumers using less cash

Jun 18, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In a Thursday, March 26, 2020 file photo, Carnival Cruise ships are docked at the Port of Tampa in Tampa, Fla. Carnival Cruise Lines says it plans to gradually resume cruising in North America in August, nearly five months after it halted operations due to the new coronavirus. Sailings will begin on Aug. 1 with eight ships setting off from Galveston, Texas; Miami; and Port Canaveral, Florida.

(AP Photo/Chris O'Meara, File)The outbreak of the coronavirus has dealt a shock to the global economy with unprecedented speed. Following are developments Thursday related to the national and global response, the work place and the spread of the virus. ________________________ TRAVEL & LEISURE: — Hong KongDisneyland officially reopened on Thursday after a major drop in coronavirus cases in the Chinese territory. Advance reservations will be required and only limited attendance will be allowed at the park, one of the pillars of Hong Kong's crucial tourism industry. Social distancing measures are being implemented in lines, at restaurants, on rides and at shops, while cleaning and disinfecting will be increased. Visitors will have their temperatures checked at the entrance and will be required to wear masks at all times inside the park, except when eating and drinking. Disney is planning to reopen its parks in California and Florida next month. — Delta Air Lines says more than 40,000 of its 91,000 employees have agreed to take unpaid leave of up to a year, which along with a 'moderate' increase in ticket sales is helping the airline cut its cash burn rate to $30 million a day by the end of this month. That is $10 million a day less than Delta forecast a week ago. Delta has raised more than $14 billion in financing and expects to have $10 billion in available funds by year end. U.S. airlines face layoffs when federal payroll aid runs out in October unless air travel rebounds. — Carnival's revenue nosedived in the second quarter as it was unable to sail any cruises. The company hasn't sailed any cruises since mid-March. For the quarter, the cruise operator reported an adjusted loss of $2.38 billion on revenue of $700 million. A year earlier it had an adjusted profit of $457 million on revenue of $4.8 billion. (Ad) The next big tech trend that could explode in today's new economy is coming to your hometown - which could make you a small fortune over the next few years.Carnival anticipates a phased resumption of its cruises, but doesn't have a specific start date. The company expects that initial sailings will be from a select number of easily accessible homeports. Carnival says it's seeing growing demand for new bookings for next year. For the six weeks ended May 31, approximately two-thirds of 2021 bookings were new bookings. The remaining 2021 booking volumes was from guests applying future cruise credits to specific cruises. CONSUMER SPENDING: Consumers are increasingly moving away from cash and opting for contact-free and digital payment experiences, according to a study by Mastercard. Globally, almost seven in 10 consumers say the shift to digital payments will likely be permanent, and nearly half of consumers plan to use cash less, even after the pandemic subsides, according to a Mastercard weekly survey launched April 27. Online spending in the U.S. grew by 93% year-over-year in May, according to Mastercard SpendingPulse, which measures retail sales across all payment types including cash and check. AUTOMOBILES: Car production in the Czech Republic fell by 52.9% in May from a year ago, with new car registration down 44.4%. The Czech Automotive Industry Association says production began to somewhat recover in May following an 88.5% decline in April, but it remains under pressure due to a lack of demand. Overall, a total of 399,681 cars were made in the country in the first five months of the year, down by 35.7% compared with the same period last year. The Czech economy relies heavily on the car industry. Germany's Volkswagen, South Korea's Hyundai and Japan-France's Toytota/PSA all have major plants in the country. CENTRAL GOVERNMENTS & BANKS: — Greece's government has announced a new system of fines and penalties for businesses that are found to be violating regulations imposed to limit the spread of the coronavirus. Under details published Thursday in the government gazette, fines for violations will range from 1,000 euros to 50,000 euros ($1,125 to $56,240). For bars and restaurants, offending businesses will be shut down for 15 days for the first violation, 30 days for the second violation and 60 days for the third if all three violations occur within three months. Other retail businesses face similar penalties, with the amount of the fines varying in accordance to whether the violation is the first, and according to the size of the business. Regulations include limits on the number of people allowed into a business depending on its physical size, distances to be maintained between tables at cafes, bars, restaurants and outdoor movie theaters, and mandatory masks to be work by staff handling fresh food. — The Spanish government has announced an economic assistance plan of more than 4.2 billion euros ($4.7 billion) for the nation's tourism industry. Tourism generates 12% of Spain's GDP and provides 2.6 million jobs. It is especially important on Spain's Balearic and Canary Islands. The aid package is aimed to help the tourism industry improve its health standards to make travel safer in times of a pandemic and offer direct lines of credit to failing companies, among other measures. Juan Cierco, head of tourism for Spain's Chamber of Commerce, said Thursday that Spain's tourism sector was in a 'critical' situation and set to lose 84 billion euros ($94 billion) this year. The government announced a separate aid package for its auto industry earlier this week.20 Stocks Wall Street Analysts Love the Most[1]Every trading day, between 500 and 800 new recommendations and research reports are issued by sell-side equities research analysts. There are between 300 and 500 brokerages and research houses that issue ratings, price targets and recommendations and more than 5,000 securities around the world that regularly receive coverage from research analysts.MarketBeat has tracked more than 170,000 distinct analyst recommendations in the last 12 months alone. Given the volume of ratings changes that occur each day, it can be difficult to sift through the noise.Analysts don't always get their "buy" ratings right, but it's worth taking a hard look when more than a dozen different analysts from different brokerages and research firm are giving "strong buy" and "buy" ratings to the same stock.This slide show lists the 20 companies that have the highest average analyst recommendations from Wall Street's equities research analysts over the last 12 months.View the "20 Stocks Wall Street Analysts Love the Most"[2]. FT premium subscribers can click here to receive Due Diligence every day by email.What were they thinking? As you already know, Hong Kong Ex...

FT premium subscribers can click here to receive Due Diligence every day by email.

What were they thinking? As you already know, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing walked away from a £32bn bid for the London Stock Exchange Group on Tuesday.

DD has spent the past 24 hours asking that question and we remain none the wiser.

HKEX’s abandoned bid effort, for which we have delved into in this feature today, can serve a useful purpose for DD readers in how not to pursue a hostile deal.

Here are a few lessons learned that everyone, including HKEX’s advisers, led by boutique bank Moelis & Company, can take away for next time:

Timing: If Charles Li, the chief executive of HKEX is to be believed, his company has been eyeing a bid for the LSE Group for the past year. For whatever reason the company never made an approach until the LSE engineered its own megadeal. Over the past year, LSE’s share price climbed rapidly and gave it a strong enough acquisition currency to pursue a deal it had been eyeing for sometime: the $27bn purchase of data provider Refinitiv. After DD broke news of that deal, LSE shares continued to climb higher and higher, a strong vote of confidence on its dealmaking decision. HKEX has defended its move saying it was now or never given the Refinitiv transaction, which it didn’t support. Bolder leadership would have acted sooner if the LSE deal was a must have.

Seduction: It takes two to tango in love and M&A. So perhaps it wasn’t the wisest move to meet with LSE officials, who are busy working on their own deal, to drop the news that you’re going to bid for them. And before the LSE had time to produce a formal response, HKEX released the offer to the entire world, with Li going so far as calling it “a corporate Romeo and Juliet story”. (Facepalm). Sure, the bid valued the LSE at a premium to where it was trading, even considering the gains from the Refinitiv news. But the HKEX bid was mostly paper, which is something completely different to cash on the table. For a hostile deal like this, cash is king. The LSE responded with cutting language, scorching any possibility of future engagement and sending HKEX on a futile multi-week journey to win over shareholders. Our reporting suggests they made only limited progress on that front.

Politics: Perhaps HKEX was comforted by its previous record of UK dealmaking. Back in 2012, it was able to successfully complete a takeover of the London Metal Exchange, which itself was sensitive albeit smaller. But has anyone at HKEX picked up a newspaper lately? Suffice it to say things have changed between the West and China over the past few years. Did the HKEX think that an acquisition of a systemically important asset, with a reasonable US presence, was ever going to fly in the current political or regulatory environment in either the UK or US?

HKEX made no compelling arguments to address the above points, which leaves us with a bunch of hard-to-answer questions:

Were HKEX executives just trying to get a break from the uprising in Hong Kong by making a bid that required ample time overseas?

Was HKEX trying an HSBC-type move to use a deal to secure a UK-headquarters over time and de-risk its governance from its home market?

Was HKEX given the greenlight by Beijing to take a run at a deeply strategic piece of market infrastructure at a crucial moment of geopolitical tensions and hope to navigate the politics with the UK and the US over the next few months?

Here is Li’s explanation in a blog post from Tuesday aptly titled Through the Looking Glass.

Drop us a line if you have the answers to these questions or to share your thoughts: and go deeper with our feature on the topic here and the Lex column here.

How do you solve a problem like Huawei?

The Trump administration has been unequivocal about just how dangerous Chinese telecoms group Huawei is to the US and its friends in the West.

It has been trying for months now to convince allies to agree to ban Huawei from their 5G networks, warning them that the Chinese company poses a threat to their security because its telecoms equipment could be used by Beijing for spying.

The only problem is that there’s no American rival to Huawei, which sells about 28 per cent of the world’s telecoms equipment. Its dominance in the industry makes it a vital asset to anyone wanting to implement 5G technology.

The Trump administration has hit upon a novel idea: What about funneling money to Huawei’s European rivals instead so that they can offer potential customers the same generous financing terms currently on offer from the Chinese company. DD thinks the likes of Nokia and Ericsson would be happy to do deals in the US.

Or the US could try to foster a homegrown rival by getting American telecoms equipment companies such as Oracle and Cisco to consider entering the radio transmission market, although they’re apparently not so keen on the prospect. Maybe throw in an incentive or two?

These are just a few of the suggestions floating around Washington, which also include potential tax breaks for American start-ups developing the next generation of telecoms technology.

But given how worried Trump officials are about this problem, any western company competing with Huawei might expect favourable treatment from the US over a range of regulatory issues — including any potential M&A activity. Happy hunting.

Hitachi: a lesson on Japanese corporate governance

Sometimes talking about your failures can be just as important as celebrating your successes.

Japanese conglomerate Hitachi isn't afraid of looking back at its brutal financial losses during the crisis. The staggering $8bn loss Hitachi suffered in 2008 marked the start of a new era for the company, which has spent the past decade unravelling its complicated corporate structure that is synonymous with many of its Japanese peers.

To many observers, Hitachi was a prime example of why Japan so badly needed a governance overhaul. It had tons of subsidiaries that owned everything from rice cookers to nuclear power plants and few independent board members.

Hitachi was operating under an old-school Japanese mentality that many of the country’s corporates are struggling to shift, even as activist investors flood into Japan’s stock market. Change is afoot, with the government taking an active role in laying down a governance code, but progress has been slow.

For companies still resisting the winds of change, Hitachi teaches an important lesson: Happy shareholders will reward the company.

Hitachi shares have more than doubled since the start of 2009, while the benchmark Topix index has climbed just over 80 per cent. The company is leaner after a clear out of its subsidiaries and there’s a clear focus on its IT and infrastructure businesses.

Read the full story from the FT’s Leo Lewis.

Job moves

Nissan has picked Makoto Uchida, the head of its China operations, as the company’s new chief executive. Uchida’s appointment follows a three-month search for a successor to Hiroto Saikawa, the handpicked appointee of former chairman Carlos Ghosn. More here.

Rebecca Thornton will succeed Karen Simon as the head of JPMorgan Chase’s director advisory services group, according to Reuters.

Food service company Aramark has named John Zillmer as chief executive to replace Eric Foss who retired from the post in the summer after activist hedge fund Mantle Ridge increased its stake in the company to 20 per cent.

Paul Hastings has hired Charles Cardon as a corporate partner in its Paris office. Cardon was previously at Dechert.

Weil, Gotshal & Manges has hired David Avery-Gee as an M&A partner in the London office. Avery-Gee joins from rival firm Linklaters.

Chris Cole’s boutique advisory firm Ardea Partners has hired Julien Petit, a Goldman Sachs dealmaker in the financial institutions group, Bloomberg reports.

Smart reads

Black Cube chronicles In a three-part series Ronan Farrow tells the tale of international efforts to suppress the Harvey Weinstein stories of sexual assault by using good old fashioned espionage and intimdiation of journalists and witnesses. ( New Yorker)

Unicorn fantasies Turning a profit is back in fashion in Silicon Valley. Over the past decade start-up valuations have been driven by how quickly companies can grow rather than how much money they can make. Burnt by the recent capital markets flops, venture capitalists now want new companies to prioritise profit. ( New York Times)

War economy Amid the rubble from war-torn Syria, a set of new players have emerged in its ravaged economy who are profiting from the nearly decade-long conflict that has torn the country apart and displaced more than 12m people. ( FT)

News round-up

German banks start merger talks to create €260bn giant (FT)

Reach in pole position to buy JPI’s regional newspapers (FT)

Vestager warns Big Tech she will move beyond competition fines (FT)

Crispin Odey hit in volatile September for hedge funds (FT)

Carlyle sees room to run in overlooked part of credit market (Bloomberg)

Juventus boss warns European football risks losing younger fans (FT)

Boeing to invest $20m in Virgin Galactic (FT)

Bessemer raises first fund for later-stage tech start-ups (FT)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WHS-HY71-JB73-154W-00000-00Hong Kong exchange sees benefits of introducing dual-class shares2019-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisREGULATIONHong Kong exchange sees benefits of introducing dual-class sharesAndrew Holt

The introduction of dual-class share listings on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong last April, designed to make the exchange a hub for technology and biotech firms, has come to fruition.

A year on from the changes, nine biotech companies have joined the Hong Kong exchange, raising a combined $3.8 bn by IPO, making Hong Kong the second-largestpublic biotech hub worldwide after leader Nasdaq, according to Refinitiv data. Over the same period, Nasdaq welcomed 57 new biotech firms, raising a combined $5.97 bn - half the global market.

The Hong Kong reforms have attracted some big tech names: smartphone giant Xiaomi raised $5.43 bn in July when it became the first dual-class shareholding company to list, while online food delivery service Meituan-Dianping raised $4.2 bn in its massive IPO last September.

Hong Kong also had six out of the top 10 biotech IPOs worldwide last year, including the top two: Shanghai medical tech platform WuXi AppTec, which raised $1.06 bn, and cancer drug developer BeiGene, which raised $902 mn.

The bad news is that most of the newly listed companies have seen their share price fall since their IPO as the stock market took something of a hit from the US-China trade war and a slowing Chinese economy. Meituan-Dianping, for example, is down 20 percent from its debut price, while Ascletis Pharma, which raised $400 mn in its IPO, has fallen by more than half.

The good news now is that the pace of listings is not stopping as a result of the market falls. The latest IPO in the pipeline is leading contract drug researcher Viva Biotech, which is looking to raise between HK$1.18 bn and HK$1.52 bn ($150 mn to $194 mn). Established in 2008, Viva provides structure-based drug-discovery services to biotechnology and pharmaceutical customers. Its stock will debut on Hong Kong's exchange on May 9.

urn:contentItem:5XFB-NH91-DXMP-K4CH-00000-00Hong Kong FinTech Week 20192019-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:14ZLexisNexisHong Kong FinTech Week 2019

Nov. 6 -- Hong Kong SAR Government issued the following news release:

The following is issued on behalf of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority:

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) today (November 6) co-organised the city's flagship fintech event with Invest Hong Kong (InvestHK). The five-day programme has attracted thousands of attendees across the globe. In his opening speech at the Hong Kong FinTech Week 2019, HKMA Chief Executive Mr Eddie Yue noted fintech development in Hong Kong has gathered remarkable momentum ever since the first FinTech Week three years ago.



The HKMA also took the chance to highlight a series of initiatives aimed to foster the fintech ecosystem in Hong Kong.

1. Blockchain collaboration with the subsidiary of Institute of Digital Currency of People's Bank of China (PBoC)

Today a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed between the subsidiaries of Hong Kong Interbank Clearing Limited and Institute of Digital Currency of the PBoC to conduct a Proof-of-Concept (PoC) trial, which aims to connect eTradeConnect (Note) and the PBoC Trade Finance Platform. The PoC is expected to begin in Q1 2020. Once the connection has successfully been established, it will provide firms in both places with more convenient trade finance services and enable banks in Hong Kong to expedite the expansion of their trade finance business.

2. Joint research with Bank of Thailand - Project LionRock-Inthanon

As a follow-up to the MoU signed between the HKMA and the Bank of Thailand in May 2019, the two authorities are conducting a joint research project named Project LionRock-Inthanon to study the application of Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) to cross-border payments, with a view to facilitating HKD-THB payment-versus-payment (PvP) among banks in Hong Kong and Thailand. A joint report is scheduled to be released in Q1 2020.

3. Bank of International Settlements (BIS) Innovation Hub Hong Kong Centre

The first ever Innovation Hub of BIS commenced its operation in Hong Kong in November 2019, a testimony that Hong Kong stands at the forefront of fintech innovation. The HKMA believes that the Innovation Hub Hong Kong Centre will serve as a focal point for regional fintech collaboration and bring the application of innovative technologies among central banks to a new level. Initially, the HKMA will explore with the Hong Kong Centre on the use of Distributed Ledger Technology to digitalise trade finance processes and study the impact of big tech to financial markets.

4. Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Banking

The HKMA is conducting a study on the application of AI technology in the banking industry and will release a series of publications. To begin with, the HKMA published today a fact sheet to highlight the key facts and figures revealed in an industry-wide survey conducted in Q3 2019. One of the key findings shows almost 90 per cent of the surveyed retail banks have adopted or plan to adopt AI applications. The survey included interviews and questionnaires conducted with banks, industry organisations, and fintech firms, with a view to understanding the current AI landscape in the banking industry. In the coming months, a series of reports will be published.

5. Fin+Tech Collaboration Platform to accelerate innovation and collaboration

The HKMA jointly launched the Fin+Tech Collaboration Platform today with the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks to support fintech development in a technology-centric approach. Industry players can make use of the platform to organise fintech-related activities such as accelerators and hackathons to explore innovative solutions, identify talents, and seek collaboration opportunities. The HKMA will also make use of the platform's hardware and software facilities for some of its fintech projects (including Project LionRock-Inthanon).

Mr Eddie Yue said, "The HKMA's fintech initiatives have successfully created a vibrant fintech ecosystem. To lift Hong Kong's fintech development to a new height, we must take a holistic 'HK Inc.' approach. I look forward to partnering with our stakeholders including financial institutions, end users, start-up firms, technology service providers, investors and regulators to walk towards the shared purposes of driving innovation, enhancing customer experience and facilitating financial inclusion."

Note: eTradeConnect is a blockchain-based trade finance platform officially launched in October 2018 under the facilitation of the HKMA and the platform is fully funded by a consortium of 12 major banks in Hong Kong.

Source: Hong Kong SAR Government

urn:contentItem:5TFS-8YD1-JDJN-63ND-00000-00Hong Kong Investment Firm Supports Development of Cryptocurrency Bank2018-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisHong Kong Investment Firm Supports Development of Cryptocurrency Bank

The start-up is building infrastructure to allow companies to pay salaries in cryptocurrencies, and bridging the disconnect between fiat and cryptocurrency payment.

While China continues to eye cryptocurrencies with a healthy dose of suspicion, acceptance, and popularity in the rest of Asia is on the increase. In fact, a Hong Kong-based firm is hopes its investment will help pave the way for a cryptocurrency bank.

According to a recent report, the firm in question has bought a stake in a cryptocurrency company, a start-up with a goal to become a licensed and authorized cryptocurrency investment bank.

The platform, which is based in the crypto hub of Zug in Switzerland is, however, still awaiting approval from the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (FINMA) to trade as a banking and securities dealer.

This approval will allow the start-up to extend to Asia and assist blockchain-based platforms to gain access to traditional banking systems. The spokesperson for the investment capital firm explained their support of the start-up by saying that the firm believes it can support the cryptocurrency start-ups plan to expand into Asia, a region where cryptocurrency trading and blockchain projects have been flourishing.

This support could extend to the start-ups ICO, which is scheduled for some time in the third quarter of next year, where the investment firm could make a contribution.

While the capital firm manages over HK$7.83 billion ($1 billion) and has interests in FinTech and logistics, this is the companys first foray into blockchain.

Both the investing firms investment amount, as well as the contribution of the U.S.-based asset management firm, have not been disclosed.

The start-ups CEO stated that the banks first focus will be on transaction banking. It was explained that it has been tough for blockchain start-ups to grow their businesses as they are unable to access the traditional banking system.

The start-up, thus, is building infrastructure to allow companies to pay salaries in cryptocurrencies, and bridging the disconnect between fiat and cryptocurrency payment.

Another reporting agency previously reported that a few surveys show that there is indeed an interest in people having parts or even all of their salaries paid in virtual currency.

The companys CEO also added that the start-up should receive the required regulatory approval in the first half of next year.

They will also eventually offer digital asset custody services to their institutional clients. In addition, the crypto bank will offer liquidity services to exchanges.

This growth in services will extend to staff numbers as the platform plans to double its number of employees by the beginning of next year.

As reported earlier, Hong Kong has been named the eighth-best city for tech enterprises, like the aforementioned start-up.

It was found that, with a score of 59%, while Hong Kong is not typically viewed as an innovation hub for tech occupiers, it is becoming more appealing for several reasons which include connectivity with Shenzhen and South China, recent expansion in Hong Kong by big tech firms such as the worlds largest social media platform and one of Chinas largest multinational conglomerates, which specialises in e-commerce, retail, Internet, AI and technology.

Moreover, tech occupiers are attracted to the accelerating investment in fintech in the city.

Moreover, the city is working to facilitate the introduction of virtual banking as another model of service delivery, with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority stating that it welcomes the establishment of virtual banks in Hong Kong, in early September 2018.

The development of virtual banks, according to the HKMA, will promote the application of financial technology [Fintech] and innovation in Hong Kong and offer a new kind of customer experience. In addition, virtual banks can help promote financial inclusion as they normally target the retail segment, including the small and medium-sized enterprises.

If Hong Kong keeps up this pace of manifestation (of the goals/objectives in the Smart City Blueprint), it will move up the ranks of the report. 2018 Global Data Point.
