Durbin Says Sen. Lee's S.386 Bill Unlikely To Get A Senate Hearing; Bolton And Kupperman Oppose Mulvaney's Bid To Join Impeachment Lawsuit; Nikki Haley: Tillerson, Kelly Tried To Recruit Me To Save The Country By Undermining Trump; Graham: Impeachment Dead On Arrival In Senate If House Dems Stop Whistleblower From Testifying; Will Hurd Reiterates Call To Protect Ukraine Whistleblower's Identity; Official Who Testified Against Trump Still Detailed To National Security Council; Mulvaney To File Own Lawsuit Tomorrow2019-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTJohn Solomon, Michael Goodwin, Tom Fitton, Kelly SadlerNEWSFinancial111101cb.229Honoring Our Veterans; Partisan Assault; House Hearings Mark New Public Impeachment Phrase; Identity Crisis: GOP Lawmakers Want Whistleblower To Testify Publicly; Witness For The Prosecution: Giuliani Associate Makes Explosive Claim On Ukraine Aid; Biden's Relationship With Ukraine; Sen. Durbin Says Sen. Lee's S.386 Bill Unlikely To Get A Senate Hearing; Bolton And Kupperman Oppose Mulvaney's Bid To Join Impeachment Lawsuit; Nikki Haley: Tillerson, Kelly Tried To Recruit Me To Save The Country By Undermining Trump; Graham: Impeachment Dead On Arrival In Senate If House Dems Stop Whistleblower From Testifying; Will Hurd Reiterates Call To Protect Ukraine Whistleblower's Identity; Official Who Testified Against Trump Still Detailed To National Security Council; Mulvaney To File Own Lawsuit TomorrowLou Dobbs, John Roberts, Ed Rollins

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. It is Monday, November 11th 2019, Veteran's Day. We begin with a special thank you and salute to our nation's veterans and all who serve the nation in uniform all around the world.

In New York City today, the commander-in-chief spoke at the city's Veteran's Day parade becoming the first president to do so. President Trump honored those who've served the nation saying the glory of their deeds only grows greater with time.

In other news tonight, it has been 48 days since the Radical Dems began their secret so-called hearings behind closed doors as they continue to try to construct their partisan assault in the constitution and the president of the United States.

Intel Committee Chairman, Adam Schiff, continues to deny fair and equitable participation of the republican members of Congress and has denied the Republicans' call to bring in their own witnesses this week. The Radical Dems and their co-conspirators, the deep state and the national leftist media have attacked President Trump unrelentingly since his election in 2016.

This week the Republican Party appears united behind the president and his public support has been unwavering in opposition to the subversive and corrosive left.

For the latest, we go to Fox Chief White House Correspondent, John Roberts.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: President Trump made history today, the first U.S. President to attend the New York City Veteran's Day parade.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You are America's greatest living heroes.

ROBERTS: He will spend one more night in New York in a speech to the economic club tomorrow before returning to Washington for the first public hearing in the impeachment inquiry.

The latest battle is over who Republicans can call as witnesses. Devin Nunes, the ranking member of the intelligence committee seeking approval from more than nine witnesses including the whistleblower and anyone he or she got the information from.

Hunter Biden, Nelly Ohr, a contractor for opposition research firm Fusion GPS. Tim Morrison, the former senior Europe and Russia expert at NSC and Kurt Volker. They want him on the panel with Bill Taylor and George Kent, Wednesday.

It's likely that at least two of those witnesses will be vetoed by Chairman Adam Schiff. In a letter to Devin Nunez, Schiff saying that having the whistleblower testify would be quote, "Redundant and unnecessary."

He also said he has no interest in quote, "Sham investigations of the Bidens." One witness that Democrats may call, Lev Parnas an associate of Rudy Giuliani's who's charged with campaign finance violations.

Fox News confirms that Parnas is prepared to tell Congress that all the way back in May, he told Ukrainian officials that in less than new government there opened an investigation to Joe and Hunter Biden, Vice President Mike Pence would not attend President Zelensky swearing in and USAID would be frozen.

What Parnas has apparently prepared to testify runs counter to everything the president Rudy Giuliani and Ukrainian officials have said.

Parnas has been subpoenaed by the House Committees for documents and testimony and told he has been producing the documents we may soon see what he has to say. Lou?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: John. Thank you very much. John Roberts from the White House. Joining us tonight award-winning Investigative Reporter, Fox Business Contributor, John Solomon. John, good to see you.

JOHN SOLOMON, AWARD-WINNING INVESTIGATIVE REPORTER: Good to be with you, Lou.

DOBBS: The first question following John Roberts' report is what makes Lev Parnas more credible than all the others who've testified or made statements directly contradicting what he said?

SOLOMON: I did want to tell tonight, I know Lev Parnas. I used him in some of my reporting. He always seemed to be an honest broker on the ground.

Let me tell you what I think the problem is for Democrats. The hearsay witnesses opine that the president had a quid pro quo. But the witnesses who actually talked to the president can only say the president said no quid pro quo.

Only the president and those people who talked to the president really know what deal was in place. And I think that that's one of the challenges the Democrats have.

They have hearsay evidence that contradicts the actual first-hand evidence of people who talk to the president. I think there's going to be a lot more new information coming out.

Specifically what other things the president might have been hearing from the intelligence community that influences thinking on Ukraine. Keep an eye on that, I think that's going to be a big development over the next week.

DOBBS: As I watch what is unfolding in Washington, listening to the testimony, reading the testimony as some of it is being released even now.

I don't see the problem here. And I'm trying to be independent and subjective as possible. I just do not understand if the president said I want with this investigation, I want to understand what the origins -- we have the Justice Department for crying out loud, investigating the origins of the 2016 assault on this president.

SOLOMON: Of course.

DOBBS: What in the world is the problem here?

SOLOMON: Yeah, and I think there's going to be a bigger issue that emerges here Lou, and that is what was the president's definition of corruption.

The media and the Democrats want to focus it on Biden in the 2016 election. I suspect that the president was getting in these intelligence briefings a much broader look at corruption and the more specifically who the new president was associated with.

President Zelensky have these relationships as everyone does with oligarchs and business people.

DOBBS: Right.

SOLOMON: I would not be surprised if the president's briefings in the May June, July timeframe give a much broader picture they once being discussed in this very narrow political exercise that the Democrats are not carrying out in Congress.

I think when we find out what the president's real basis for understanding why he was making these requests when that becomes public, I think we're going to have a different picture, much like we got when we learn the real story on Russia.

DOBBS: Yeah, the real story, it is the story is it? Speaking of the real story, the Solomon report in whi8ch you're saying the Obama administration tried in 2016 to partner with Burisma while Hunter Biden was sitting on their board apparently the administration thought that that might pose something called corruption concerns.

SOLOMON: Yeah, absolutely. You know, one of the most interesting parts of the impeachment testimony that the Democrats and media aren't focusing on is just how concerned members of the state department in the NEC and others were concerned about Joe Biden and Hunter Biden's relationship with Burisma.

They saw conflict of interest in 2015. They were concerned when the State Department tried to do a co-project or a joint project with Burisma through Hunter Biden and Devon Archer. And they actually put a stop to it because of the corruption allegations that's surrounded that company.

This isn't an event that Rudy Giuliani or I or anyone else invented, the Democrats in 15 and 16 had their concerns long before I reported it. Rudy Giuliani did his research. That's the part that's missing from this narrative and Joe Biden seems to be the only person that doesn't see a problem with what went on between him and Hunter Biden and Burisma.

DOBBS: The witnesses who would discuss exactly that issue.

SOLOMON: That's right.

DOBBS: The New York Times reporting yesterday by vice president Biden concerned about their Burisma job. We're not saying a broad effort on the part of a left-wing national medial to deal with the story and to give that some focus as you were talking about the broader truth that's going to be revealed. They're only grudgingly touching the margins of this story right now.

SOLOMON: Yeah. You know there were some ABC News has done a good job. I think the Washington Post from time to time speak up a few things in New York times, a couple of times.

There is a very clear narrative, the documents I saw it enforce the release of last week at the State Department clearly show that Hunter Biden's company was lobbying the State Department to help make the corruption allegations go away in Ukraine right the beginning of the 2016 electi0n.

And when they approached that State Department, they invoked Hunter Biden's name as the reason why they needed help. That is the sort of conflict of interest that ethics laws in Washington were created to avoid and I think as we dig in further in the next couple of months, I'm going to give another trench of documents from the court we order really soon.

DOBBS: Right.

SOLOMON: I think we're going to learn a lot more about what those State Department bureaucrats, NEC bureaucrats were doing in the middle of the 2016 election to address this Burisma crisis that Joe Biden was facing.

DOBBS: I want to touch on another topic here if we may in which you're suggesting the president has a tremendous strategic opportunity here. His Berlin wall moment as you style it.

SOLOMON: Right. Yeah, you know all this distraction with impeachment, Russia collusion, all of the things we've been talking about has blinded the media with some of the developments going on in the Middle East.

And I think right now, this president has set in motion a dynamic that we have not seen in certainly my lifetime in the Middle East. We are seeing regional partners, I'm talking his frenemies, having conversations that they haven't had in a long time, trying to broker settlements beneath of United States that make this region more stable.

And I think a lot of that has to do with the fact that Trump simultaneously pulled out the troops and managed to get al-Baghdadi, showing that we can strong even while we pursue a piece.

I think there's a big story being missed in the Middle East. I think president trump has put together a unique opportunity to create peace in the Middle East and I think Donald Trump has put into motion a very unique opportunity.

I'll be at fragile, a unique opportunity to create peace in the Middle East.

DOBBS: Well, I think that the fact of the matter is the national leftist media again is only grudgingly beginning to look at the reality that's emerging from a decision that once again this president is, if you will, disrupted the orthodox ANC said of course which seems to be as usual a course that has tremendous benefits beyond what the orthodoxy ever imagined.

SOLOMON: I had a democratic senator when I first came to Washington in 1990, a guy name Bill Proxmire very wise man and he said something that's always stuck in the back of my head, if you're going to be a disrupter, you're going to ruffle feathers and sometimes you got to wait for the feathers to clear before you see the truth of what happened.

I think that's a lot of Donald Trump's president. We're just beginning to see the things he have done because of disruption.

DOBBS: Right. And just because that Donald Trump, we're seeing a lot of benefits across foreign policy, domestic policy, and economic policy without a doubt. John Solomon as always, great to see you my friend.

SOLOMON: Thank you, sir. Appreciate it.

DOBBS: This broadcast has been reporting for weeks now about a senate bill that serves to accelerate the flow of Indian H-1B visas into the United States, directly, directly competing with U.S. workers with lower wages.

We're now learning that the chief sponsor of that legislation in the senate, Senator Mike Lee, is refusing to hold a public hearing on the bill. Senator Dick Durbin who has a competing bill says Lee won't take up a broader debate on an alternate proposal put forward by Democrats or on his own Senate Bill 386, known as the Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act which already passed in the House as HR-1044.

Now, talking with reporters Durbin calls Lee's refusal for open hearings and debate unusual. Let me say what I mean here and I don't mean unusual, I mean it's scurrilous. It is absolutely beneath contempt and he should be ashamed, as we detailed here before.

Senator Lee has taken in thousands of dollars in this election cycle from some of the top sponsors of H-1B visas and outsourcers including big tech firms, Google, Microsoft, Facebook, and Amazon.

It is more than interesting that a report released earlier this year finds that the Salt Lake City Metro area is second, second only to Silicon Valley in the percentage of commercial leases signed by technology companies last year.

Lee has tried and failed four times to force his bill through the Senate by the device known as unanimous consent, which does not require votes of the supporting Senators of course or even the opposing Senators should there be one or two.

It is deeply concerning that Senator Lee seems to have the support of another Republican, Senator John Cornyn. He says Durbin's quote, "Delay tactics won't work." A delay tactic in calling for hearings and public debate that certainly Senator Lee's bill requires before it should be allowed to pass in any form, in any senator, in my opinion should definitely give the public a chance to air their thoughts about this very important critical legislation that sets up direct competition with U.S. workers.

And I would hope that the president would go so far as to ask Senator Lee and Senator Durbin to back off their bills and for Senator McConnell to take charge of the Senate and set this up for debate if we are to have a debate about a bill that will directly set up more intense competition with U.S. workers.

It is unfair, it is unreasonable, and it is a fraud on the American worker.

Up next, the Supreme Court gears up for what could be one of the countries defining immigration court cases. We take that up and more.

Border Patrol Union President Brandon Judd joins us here. Also Nikki Haley sharing tales of subversion treachery in the White House. I wonder, did she tell the president? We'll find out. We'll take that up and more right after this quick messages, stay with us.

DOBBS: Another record-setting day on Wall Street, not a lot of action, but the Dow importantly up 10 points closing at its 9th record close of the year.

The S&P losing 6, the NASDAQ fell 11, no records there. Volume on the big board, the volume backing up to 3.1. Billion shares and crude oil down over a half percent to just under $57 a barrel. Gold lost nearly a half percent, silver closed flat.

Boeing expected to resume deliveries of its grounded 737 max jetliners next month. It could start commercial flights as early as January.

Boeing 737 Max's have been ground since March after two deadly crashes, 346 people killed in those crashes. Boeing stock is up nearly 5 percent in after-hours trading on the news about the possibility of a January flight for the 737 Max's.

New documents revealing Southwest Airlines is continuing to fly 38 of its 737 aircraft, even though they don't have their final safety verifications.

According to the documents an FAA official recommended grounding those aircraft for lacking adequate maintenance records. The FAA has given southwest until the end of January to complete thorough inspections of those 38 jetliners.

Well, a reminder to listen to my reports three times a day coast-to- coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney today asked a court to decide whether he should appear before Congress to take part in the Radical Dems sham impeachment farce.

Mulvaney is trying to join a lawsuit put forth by former National Security John Bolton and his deputy Charles Kupperman who are also asking the courts to decide if they should either obey the White House directions or the subpoena of Congress.

An attorney for Bolton and Kupperman oppose the move by Mulvaney arguing their cases are different to Mulvaney's as he still works at the White House. We'll see if that is a distinction or a distinction without a difference.

Former Ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley with a new book in which she reveals former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and former White House Chief of Staff John Kelly tried to recruit her to subvert President Trump and his agenda.

Haley telling CBS Tillerson and Kelly insisted they weren't subverting the President but were, quote, "Trying to save the country."

Joining us, tonight former Reagan White House Political Director, Fox Business Political Analyst, Ed Rollins. Fox Business Contributor and New York Post Columnist, the Pulitzer Prize winning Michael Goodwin. Good to have you both here.

Let's start with your assessment of the Nikki Haley revelations that Tillerson and Kelly were trying to subvert the president and look for her assistance.

ED ROLLINS, FOX BUSINESS POLITICAL ANALYST: Well, I don't know what assistance she could have given other than a P.R. perspective. At the end of the day, she was not a decision maker. She sits up here and basically deals with foreign nations and casts votes.

But she doesn't make the decisions on the votes. The decision is made by the president with the advising council of the sector of state. So to me, it's kind of a strange story and is kind of disturbing story.

Equally as important, what are the issues that they're arguing about? And I assume that they weren't winning their way with Trump and they weren't winning their way with Trump and the Secretary of State and the chief of staff of the White House, they're not going to win with Nikki or 20 other people in the cabinet.

The president has made up his mind what he wanted to do, that's why it should be.

MICHAEL GOODWIN, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I'm also reminded of the Rod Rosenstein story, the allegations that he talked about invoking the 25th amendment. I would also draw a distinction between Rex Tillerson and General Kelly.

Tillerson was well-known for going around the world and bad mouthing the president, telling the foreign leaders you don't have to listen to him, and pay no attention.

Kelly's response to Nikki Haley's book I thought was interesting because he said, you know if by subverting, you mean trying to set up a process where the president heard all sides and we made methodical decisions, I plead guilty.

So, there seem to be very different versions of what they were proposing to her. And as Ed said there's something strange about it.

DOBBS: Let's put up the Kelly response if we may so that everyone can see this. He said if by resistance and stalling she means putting a staff process in place to ensure the president knew all the pros and cons of what policy decision he might be contemplating so he could make an informed decision than guilty as charged."

That doesn't seem here regular, but on the other hand, it could be interpreted a lot of ways.

ROLLINS: It would have been better if none of this has been said and her book publicly -- what Kelly did is Kelly came into a White House in somewhat disarray. Both men and in previous didn't - had never been in government then didn't quite understand how to set it up.

Kelly obviously did, Kelly understood orderly processes because of his long career in the military and having been the cabinet secretary and I don't think he did anything in those against the president. He did something to basically the president system work better.

DOBBS: Personally, I think it seems to me that the assessment of a chaos was more of a, if you will, an establishment and left wing and RINO view of the White House at that point.

And I think that this president by the way has functioned very well with a lean staff. He is the decision maker, the fed doesn't sound too much like George W. Bush.

(LAUGHTER)

GOODWIN: The decider.

DOBBS: With the decider in chief here. But it is true, he has a remarkable adroit group of people around him right now.

ROLLINS: He basically knows what he wants to do, and the reality is he's the one that got the votes, he's the one that gets to do it.

DOBBS: And now we've got to turn to Lindsey Graham who said this, if we can put this up, we got Lindsey Graham on the importance of the whistleblower to the so-called this impeachment farce and its process.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, (R-SC): It's impossible to bring this case forward in my view fairly without us knowing who whistleblower is and having a chance to cross-examine them about any biases they may have.

So, if they don't call the whistleblower in the House, this thing is dead on arrival in the Senate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Michael?

GOODWIN: Well, it should be dead on arrival but I don't know that Lindsey Graham is going to be able to make that call alone. I assume there will be some summary dismissal motion made on the floor by a Senate Republican and if you can get 50 vote for it, then it would be dead on arrival.

But at this point, we only know this is Lindsey Graham talking. We don't know if its Mitch McConnell is even behind this?

DOBBS: But he's talking sense?

GOODWIN: Oh yes.

ROLLINS: As I said on the show weeks ago, a CIA operative who was in the CIA building and not in the White House doing investigation and spy work on the president.

The first question I would ask is where did you get your information? How did you find out what was going on? He's made the charge and now they all basically want to say, well we've back the charges up, well they haven't the charges up.

What is his motives? How did he get it? How did he get his information? And if he was basically spying in those country and spying on the president of the United States, he should be fired and probably jailed.

DOBBS: Should we be saying the whistleblower's name out loud?

ROLLINS: I don't care.

GOODWIN: If we're certain, absolutely.

DOBBS: There you go. Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin, thank you both. Appreciate it.

Up next, why does one of the Dems' sham impeachment witnesses get to keep his job in the National Security Council? Touching, isn't it? Or is it just troubling.

We take that up and more. Judicial Watch's Tom Fitton with us right after this quick break. Stay with us.

DOBBS: RINO Congressman Will Hurd says the so-called whistleblower's identity should be protected. Hurd, though is a former CIA officer who is giving his post up in congress next year. He disagrees House Intel Ranking Member Devin Nunes' request to have the whistleblower publicly testify.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. WILL HURD (R-TX): It's how we've treat this whistleblower will impact whistleblowers in the future. Having this whistleblower law on the books is important. It's an important checks and balance. I'm not only in the intelligence community, but our government --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, whistleblower or is he a leaker or is he a spy? The Former CIA Officer Congressman Hurd was an undercover officer for the CIA in the Middle East and South Asia for nearly a decade.

He's one of three former CIA agents in congress. The others are all Democrats. Congresswoman Abigail Spanberger, Elissa Slotkin. There's also a former FBI agent in the House, Republican Brian Fitzpatrick.

Well, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman will reportedly remain on the National Security Council, even after providing testimony against President Trump.

Vindman's attorney says his client will stay on as a Ukraine expert until his detail ends in July of next year. That's really strange, isn't it?

Well, joining us now to tell us what he thinks of that and more, Tom Fitton, he's the President of Judicial Watch. And there are a lot of strange things for us discuss -- to discuss here tonight.

Tom, let's start out with Vindman. What is the deal? Robert O'Brien, the national security advisor, he is restructuring the National Security Council and its staff, why not just move him, his brother, whomever, out?

TOM FITTON, JUDICIAL WATCH PRESIDENT: I don't know. He shouldn't be there. If I were the president, I don't know how we can expect the president to have any trust in this person's work.

Obviously, given his personal dislike for the president and his policies. This is as man who substituted his views on what Ukraine should be doing for the views of the president of the United States.

To me, it should mean that he should be nowhere near any policy making body for the government. So, I guess the line is, he'll just move along when his detail is over. And I don't think they should wait for the detail to be over.

DOBBS: Yeah, it makes you wonder what kind of rational process there is available because here is -- as you say, I mean, the president clearly wouldn't trust who doesn't care for the president's policies on Ukraine.

Why put up with that? Why not just give him something else to do? He's after all a public servant, serving in uniform at least when he's testifying against the president. He might be better used in another post where he would be credible, perhaps, and have greater opportunity.

FITTON: You know, and this is another example of how the deep state is able to work its ways. You have all these detailee's going over to National Security Council.

Many of whom don't appreciate the president or support him. And similarly, you have detailee's going over and work with Congress to undermine the president of the United States.

You've got federal officials, federal employees working with the majority in congress. I bet you right now on this coup effort.

DOBBS: Yeah, that's an interesting point. And you know, maybe the president could maybe go over to the Pentagon and spend more time with -- rather than having to send people or drop over to the CIA, just kind of, you know, have coffee with them from time to time.

FITTON: Reform is needed, Lou. We've got to protect the republic from these administrative overlords.

DOBBS: It's stunning. And there he is, let's be clear, Vindman referred to the interagency. And my goodness, there was a reverence in the words on paper.

As he spoke them in his opening statement, I mean, he talks about the interagency as you would expect say he would refer to the commander-in- chief to the White House, to the Pentagon, to the command structure, no. He worships at the altar of the interagency. It is stunning stuff.

FITTON: Well, these are the -- this is the Praetorian Guard that the attorney general has warned us about. These are individuals in the administration or in any administration, who believe they know better than the elected president of the United States.

And this is the harm that's being done to our republic. You have individuals who disagree with the president of policy -- on policy who are being brought in to suggest that that disagreement means he needs to be removed from office.

And that is a fundamental threat to our constitutional republic. And just look, you know, this is the alleged whistleblower whose name we're not supposed to mention. You know, he was a CIA officer allegedly over in the White House. Now, we got the documents about who he was visiting with.

DOBBS: I've got to -- I've got do this because you mentioned the word, whistleblower. No, I'm kidding. I'm kidding.

FITTON: Yeah.

DOBBS: We've got a -- we've a got a hard commercial break in about seven seconds. If you would please stay with us to the commercial break and we'll take up whistleblower next. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking news tonight, Mick Mulvaney will have to file his own law suit tomorrow in order to ask a judge whether to decide -- to decide whether he should comply with a subpoena from the -- well, the Radical Dems in congress who are carrying out their farce of an inquiry.

A judge today, making the decision that he would not allow Mulvaney to join a lawsuit by John Bolton's Deputy Charles Kupperman and Bolton himself.

We're back with Tom Fitton, the president of Judicial Watch and I want to continue our discussion about Will Hurd and the whistleblower.

But, first, I want to -- I'll get your assessment of this breaking news now that Bolton and Kupperman will have their own separate lawsuit apart from Mulvaney.

FITTON: Well, in some ways it's not surprising, I haven't seen the judge's ruling. But I suspect that you have -- just different legal issues and the judge says you've got to pursue this lawsuit separately, Mr. Mulvaney.

But either way, you've now have three officials lawfully objecting to a subpoena by Congress. And what is the coup cabal saying in response to that?

You're objecting in federal court to our request following the rule of law as evidence of guilt. And it's a reason to remove the president. This is the Alice in Wonderland over carrying the constitution approach that the Pelosi-Schiff coup cabal is engaging in.

DOBBS: Yeah. And in each instance, we're talking about absolute denial of due process.

FITTON: That's right.

DOBBS: We're talking about overriding executive privilege. And we're talking about a process that does not include the second party of this two- party system operating without precedent, without participation, without equity, and without any right to call their own witnesses or to cross- examine. It's ridiculous. It is -- and its worse, a dark farce.

FITTON: And the -- and the worst part of it as we talk about last night, Lou, is the protection of this alleged whistleblower. The idea that this person who is alleged to have improperly change -- exchange information with Mr. Schiff who lied about it.

Who may have been improperly talking about the presidential phone call which is classified at the time internally within the administration, that he wouldn't be questioned about what he knew and when and who he was talking to and what they were talking to -- they were talking about like Mr. Colonel Vindman.

It's an abomination of the law here. And I'll you, we're asking questions about what the -- now, there's a name out there associated with the whistleblower.

We've looked at the White House visitor logs under Barack Obama and saw that he had -- at least two meetings with related to the Ukraine issue specifically with the Soros groups tied in this effort by Ukrainians to target President Trump. So --

DOBBS: Which Soros' groups?

FITTON: This is the Ukrainian Soros group that leaked the black ledger, Lou.

DOBBS: Right.

FITTON: Two meetings with this -- with this person. And I don't know if he's the whistleblower, but is it interesting the Obama White House is meeting with this person.

And is it interesting that no one wants to talk to the CIA official assigned to the both the Obama White House and the Trump White House to handle Ukraine. Why isn't he being questioned irrespective of whether he's a whistleblower.

DOBBS: All good points and Will Hurd insisting that the whistleblower, quote, unquote, and we use the expression whistleblower but he doesn't fit the classic definition of whistleblower, does he?

Because the actions that we're -- he's whistle blowing were outside the intelligence community, were they not?

FITTON: Look, he's not a whistleblower under the law. And the classic definition of the whistleblower is someone who sees something wrong and tells their superiors about it.

He went to congress initially, as I said improperly and maybe talked about classified information which would raise significant legal issues for him.

So you know, we've worked with whistleblowers here all the time at Judicial Watch. This is the -- this is the opposite whistle blowing. This is leaking. This is conspiracy. And Adam Schiff's involved in it and he's making decisions where the American people will know about his involvement. He's conflicted and should be kicked off the impeachment inquiry if it's to proceed sat all.

DOBBS: Tom Fitton, as always, great to have you with us. Thanks, Tom.

FITTON: You're welcome. A major court case will be heard tomorrow in Washington. The Supreme Court set to hear oral arguments tomorrow over President Trump's 2017 decision to abolish DACA.

Three separate nationwide injunctions have previously prohibited the Trump administration from ending the Obama-era program all together. Snowy conditions today across the Midwest creating a frightening situation for some passengers at Chicago's O'Hare airport.

The flight originating from GreensboroughNorth Carolina sliding off the runway at O'Hare, after landing with visibility less than a mile. Wind goes up to 30 miles an hour.

American airlines blamed icy conditions for the incident, no one aboard. Was injured, we are pleased to report. We want to hear your thoughts on all of this.

Share your comments, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. And on a programming note, the Republican National Committee's Ronna McDaniel and Director of Citizenship and Immigration Services Ken Cuccinelli among our guests here tomorrow evening. We hope you'll join us.

Well, up next, a secret Google project. Apparently has found a new invasive way to mine your personal data. We'll have that story and what's being done about it if anything, right after these messages. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Google has reported to have begun gathering personal health data of millions of Americans, according to the Wall Street Journal.

Google started that project nightingale as it's called last year. They partnered with Ascension, which is the nation's second largest healthcare system.

The two have gathered healthcare information on people across 21 states. And they apparently have done so without notifying doctors or patients.

Google claims that project is completely in line with federal law. And if it is, in my humble opinion, federal law had better get changed and now.

Well, joining us, Kelly Sadler, former assistant -- special assistant to the president, she is now director of communications at America First Policies and America First Action, that action part. I really like it.

KELLY SADLER, FMR SPECIAL ASSISTANT TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: Yeah, action. We're going into action for the president.

DOBBS: Good to see you.

SADLER: Nice to see you, Lou.

DOBBS: And I have to say, if Google is doing this, the president talked about taking on big tech before anybody else.

SADLER: Yeah. Yeah.

DOBBS: Is he going to take on big tech because this is really getting outrageous when they can do something like this with a healthcare group.

SADLER: Yeah -- no. It seems like this is a bipartisan issue on the hill too --

DOBBS: Absolutely.

SADLER: -- in terms of people looking into antitrust suits against Google, what they are doing with this information that they are accumulating.

We've already know that, you know, they had to pay out, you know, over 100 million dollars, I think $170 million because YouTube was illegally gathering information about children and consumers and then basing ads on that.

DOBBS: This is a big issue.

SADLER: Yeah.

DOBBS: Privacy and data being that is being exploited by big tech and others. It got to be dealt with --

SADLER: Yeah. And then -- and then them not notifying, you know, the consumers that they are gathering this information, there was a breach or and -- not wanting to release this like with Google+ because they don't want to get into any regulatory affairs in D.C.

DOBBS: Well, let's get into the nuts and bolts of campaigning 2020 and we're looking at polls on suburban women. It seems to be an issue for the president. How big an issue is it?

SADLER: Well, I don't think it's that big of an issue and let me tell you why.

DOBBS: Sure.

SADLER: The campaign just released some information about, you know, basically, they've had over 10,000 women suburban donors, big money donors that have contributed more than $8 million to the campaign. That puts the president number one in kind of this large group of women suburban donors among all of the campaigns including the Democratic races that are going on.

And we've been doing focus groups with suburban women across America and what we've found is that the hidden Trump vote is a real one that you have to kind of pullout from these women.

Like -- they don't like talking about politics, they don't like talking about the -- you know, this kind of -- they don't like getting into it, but once they do, they recognize that this president has provided them, you know, the lowest unemployment rate in 65 years.

The child tax care credit was doubled under his tax cut act. They recognize the good policies but then say, you know, but we never put a Trump bumper sticker on our car.

DOBBS: Because of the perceived suburban consensus.

SADLER: There was one woman who said I don't want my car to be knifed.

DOBBS: Yeah, well --

SADLER: And have that backlashed. And they don't want to get into these arguments.

DOBBS: Did your polling show anything like this during the 2016 campaign, an aversion to publicly supporting the president?

Well, we weren't around in 2016. We're coming for as to re-elect the package. But one of the things that my boss, Brian Walshaw (ph) says is that, this hidden vote is real.

And that the pundits and the political elites back in 2016 totally dismissed it, and the polls were wrong. And these are the people that are never put -- you know, put up in polls because they just don't respond to these questions. They don't want to respond.

DOBBS: And the president making it very clear, the president will make whatever adjustments required to fix those things, I have no doubt.

He's also trying to make the Republican Party understand not to be led into a fool's trap. That is too many Republican office holders have said the president's call with Zelensky was okay. But part of it was bad and but it was not impeachable.

SADLER: Yeah.

DOBBS: What -- just read the transcript. These lawmakers need to read the transcript. It's out there. There are three things that are not in the transcript.

No speak of the 2020 re-election. There is no quid pro quo and there's no withholding of aid. The only thing that we're seeing here is these lawmakers -- this hidden, you know, kangaroo court.

Basically where there's no due justice, no due process for the president. The lawmakers need to read the transcript and have the president's back here because he did nothing wrong and the call was perfectly fine and he's well within his presidential powers of foreign policy to have that call.

DOBBS: any one of those congressman or senators should have the intelligence and the understanding of law and public policy and politics to understand you support the president, you don't play at it. You support it.

SADLER: Yeah.

DOBBS: Particularly when the state of the future of the party is at stake. Kelly, great to have you with us.

SADLER: Thanks so much, Lou. I appreciate it.

DOBBS: Thanks so much. Up next. The commander-in-chief honors the service and sacrifice of our nation's veterans. We'll have his message right after this quick break. Stay with us.

DOBBS: President Trump today becoming the first commander-in-chief ever to attend the New York City Veterans Day parade. President Trump has a long history with the parade.

In 1995 organizers had received zero donations. Until then businessman Donald J. Trump stepped in and gave somewhere around $350,000 to the parade.

That unleashed a windfall of contributions to the parades organizers and saved the parade. During a speech today, President Trump hailed the legacy of America's Armed Forces and honored their many sacrifices.

That's it for us tonight. We thank you for being with us here tonight. Tomorrow night we will have Ronna McDaniel, the head of the RNC, and Ken Cuccinelli, the head of Citizenship and Immigration Services that's tomorrow.

We hope you'll be with us for that and much more. Thanks for being with us this evening. Good night from New York.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YBH-SWP1-F12B-J0B7-00000-00Hooked How sellers get us to bite2020-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSPg. A018Hooked How sellers get us to bite

They pass around your private information and manipulate your attention so they can sell it. Yet still we spend hours a day on the world's biggest social media platforms - but should we? This Herald series explains exactly what's at stake when you like your friend's Facebook post, Google symptoms when you're sick and share fake news. Damien Venuto and Chris Keall report

She was six months' pregnant when the anti-abortion lobbying started coming in.

Auckland mum-to-be Natalia Lopez had grown used to the steady stream of cots, prams and baby onesies that mirrored her online searches.

The same could not, however, be said when she scrolled down her newsfeed to see a graphic anti-abortion video clip from Family First buried among posts from family and friends.

She'd never seen anything from the organisation before and it seemed strange to suddenly be receiving messages so pertinent to her situation.

The video was titled "Before you defend abortion, be sure to understand what you're defending" and featured a graphic animation of a foetus being ripped apart limb by limb during a second trimester abortion.

"What disturbs me most about it was that they didn't know what I was going through when I was targeted with these ads," Lopez told the Herald.

"I could have been in the middle of making one of the toughest decisions a woman can make and to have a lobby group pushing their view on to me just didn't seem right."

Lopez was further annoyed because the information was skewed to favour the anti-abortion argument: "It was all emotionally loaded. And the animation also depicted the foetus much larger and with more defined features than you would see during that stage of the pregnancy."

Lopez tagged the video as misleading and hasn't seen anything from Family First since. (The Herald checked with national director Bob McCoskrie, who told us the video was targeted at anyone over 18 and that 142,000 people had watched it on Facebook.)

This is simply the world we live in. Social media firms know when we're engaged, pregnant, on holiday, sick or worried about balding. Companies watch our movements online to ensure they can feed us the most relevant information - in the hope of securing that sale.

Lopez could, of course, simply quit Facebook. But in 2020, that's not so easy. The likes of Facebook, the Facebook-owned Instagram and WhatsApp, and Twitter have become integral to how we keep up with family and friends. And for most of us, they're intertwined with our work lives, too.

For most of us, checking our social feeds is the first thing we do when we wake, and the last thing we do before sleeping. And in between those social media bookends to our day, we spend a staggering six hours online each day on average. But how much do you really know about those social media platforms and what data they are collecting about you?

Think about everything you've googled. Your secrets, your health concerns, your symptoms, your hopes, insecurities - everything punched into an algorithm and stored out of view until it later becomes relevant. How much is all this information worth? And how powerful is it?

And did you know that your attention is being manipulated to keep you on these platforms so your attention can be sold to advertisers? You're not just getting a newsfeed from the friends and family you follow - an algorithm has tracked your interests and dishes up the posts that will keep you hooked. The company introduced the 'like' button on its posts so you keep going back for that dopamine hit.

As Steve Andriole recently wrote for Forbes, "Every time we blog, tweet, post, rideshare, order from Amazon, rent an Airbnb - or anything that leaves a digital trail - we feed into this surveillance capitalism".

You may have been broadly aware Facebook tailors your newsfeed to interests you've revealed while using it. But did you know Facebook tracks you even when you're not using it?

We know this because in January Facebook launched its Activity Tracker feature that reveals many businesses share your real-world activity with the social media giant.

Facebook is to be commended for finally making this information transparent - albeit with some nudging from regulators and politicians - but the scope of its information-harvesting is still staggering.

For example, even if you love Domino's but have never mentioned it on Facebook - or even pizza - the social network might still throw up ads for a discount off your next Simply Cheese.

That's because Domino's is one of thousands of companies that have a business relationship with Facebook that sees them share your so-called "off-Facebook" activity - which might be a visit to a website, a search, or a purchase from one of its stores.

Facebook says sensitive data, such as health and financial information, are not included in the information trading. But the Wall Street Journal and others have noted health and fitness, weight-loss, heart-rate and maternity wear and even ovulation apps have shared information with the social network.

A Wall Street Journal reporter complained about targeted apps related to her recent download of the What to Expect pregnancy app. Privacy International, a British-based charity, reported in September that several menstruation cycle-tracking apps have been sharing their users' intimate details with the social network - including the last time a user had unprotected intercourse. These apps included Maya (more than five million downloads) and Period Tracker MIA Fem: Ovulation Calculator (over two million users).

Better news: Facebook now lets you see most of the businesses that have shared information about you, and a broad outline of the activity they've recorded (it says for "technical reasons" not everything is revealed to you. And that includes, for example, items you put in an online shopping cart).

While logged in to Facebook, navigate to "Office Facebook Activity" through settings or visit it directly here. From that screen, you can also turn off tracking, company by company, if you don't like personalised ads. But pack a lunch. This reporter had 595 apps and websites sharing off-Facebook activity (including the Herald, among other local and international publishers).

Turning each one off takes time.

Facebook does offer an option to zap all sharing at once. Go to facebook.com/off - facebook - activity/activity - list then click Manage Future Activity. But there is a catch - you'll be logged out of sites and services where you've chosen to log on using your Facebook details - a handy time saver. For those sites - if you want to turn them off - you'll have to change your account details so you log on with your email address and a password. (Facebook is banking on you finding this too inconvenient, and throwing in the towel).

98 pieces of information

The Washington Post recently revealed that Facebook actively tries - through monitoring your on and off-Facebook activity - to discover 98 separate pieces of information about you to help it make the billions of dollars it does every year through targeted ads.

According to a Washington Post story which revealed how the social network targets advertisers, the 98 points include perhaps unsurprising things such as your gender and age, but also whether your politics are conservative or liberal, whether you're a heavy buyer of alcohol, the groceries you buy and types of holidays you enjoy.

If you think that sounds Big Brother, take a smidgen of comfort from the fact Facebook is less intrusive than it used to be. The Cambridge Analytica scandal in 2018 revealed that people who took a personality test on Facebook in 2016 (including 63,714 Kiwis) not only shared their personal data with Donald Trump's presidential campaign (via fine print most had not read) but inadvertently volunteered their Facebook friends' data to be shared, without their knowledge, as well.

That loophole is now closed, but there's still plenty of snooping going on, even if these days it's confined to your own account.

To retake control, visit Facebook.com/settings. Then click on the Ads tab, then your interests. From there, you can delete various "interests" that Facebook has assigned to you. You can also opt out of ads that are delivered to your feed based on your relationship, employment or education, or data provided by partners.

While you're on the Facebook settings screen, also review your Privacy options - who sees various elements of your profile, and who sees posts or photos by default.

But do note that you have to separately visit the Location and Face Recognition tags to stop tracking or your location displayed or your face being automatically recognised and tagged as you when friends take pictures.

And also bear in mind that you have to make regular repeat visits to Facebook.com/settings as the goalposts frequently shift.

Help on the way

After the Christchurch mosque shootings, the Australian Government has taken a notably more front-foot approach than ours to cracking down on social media.

A law change means social media platforms can now be fined up to 10 per cent of their revenue, or their executives jailed for three years, if they fail to take "swift" action to take down "abhorrent" content.

The ACCC - the Aussie equivalent to our main consumer watchdog, the Commerce Commission - received a A$27 million top-up in December, earmarked for extra monitoring of digital platforms.

And late last year, the ACCC filed a federal case against Google alleging it misled consumers into thinking they had disabled location-tracking - when, in fact, the search giant was still able to track their every move - not realising that what seemed a one-stop process actually required two steps (our Commerce Commission is keeping a "watching brief" on the case. Google is defending the action and since the period of alleged offending has added its incognito mode, mentioned above).

The Harmful Digital Communications Act (2015) has given Kiwis a useful tool when they think they are being cyberbullied. The law came with an "approved agency" to enforce it: NetSafe, which can advocate on your behalf if you have an issue with the likes of Facebook, Twitter or Google.

In terms of concerns about the social media platforms invading your privacy, the Privacy Act (1993) has not been a hugely effective tool - unsurprisingly, given it was authored before the internet went mainstream.

An update to the Act is still going through Parliament (it passed its second reading late last year) but is expected to go into force this year.

Privacy Commissioner John Edwards did not get several items on his wishlist, including the ability to levy fines of up to $1m on misbehaving companies, or a provision for "data portability" - meaning you own information collected about you, rather than the company which harvested it, and you can take it with you after you close an account.

But he did get others included, such as mandatory data breach disclosure - so soon, any organisation will have to tell you if it loses your data to hackers.

And, in terms of social media privacy for everyday users, Edwards points to two new powers his office will enjoy under the new law. First, "It clarifies the law so there is no room for ambiguity about overseas companies and whether they come under the jurisdiction of our privacy law," he says.

In a 2018 stoush with the Privacy Commissioner's office, Facebook said it need not comply with the NZ Privacy Act because it had no office here.

"When the Privacy Bill comes into force, I'll have the ability to issue compliance notices to business to improve the digital environment for consumers, whether you are based here, or just doing business here," Edwards said.

The Privacy Commissioner said he would take aim at "click-to-consent", or one-click acceptance of terms and conditions that can run to thousands of words of legalese. His message to Big Tech: Attempts to bury privacy-invasion provisions deep in the fine print must stop. While he is optimistic, it could be that test cases are required, given Facebook's moving-feast terms and conditions have variously had its NZ membership under Irish and now US privacy law - at least in its view.

He would prefer the Big Tech companies take what he calls a "privacy by design" approach, with elements such as location tracking and face-recognition turned off by default, and only enabled with informed user consent. As things stand, we're some distance from his ideal.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WH3-8121-JC8S-D2R4-00000-00Hopefuls aim at corporate giants2019-07-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B004Hopefuls aim at corporate giantsMike Dorning

1) Sen. Elizabeth Warren, as have other Democratic presidential hopefuls, is attacking monopolies. PHOTO: Justin Kaneps / New York Times

Elizabeth Warren slammed Washington for failing to challenge giant corporations. Bernie Sanders assailed the power of Wall Street and the pharmaceutical industry. Cory Booker vowed to appoint more judges and antitrust enforcers and even Joe Biden is preparing a trust-busting plan. Democratic presidential hopefuls are coming out in force against the rapid pace of corporate consolidation, a message to 2020 voters that gained volume during their first debates in Miami last week.

They're expanding their pledges to take on big tech, including Facebook and Alphabet, to other industries. Attacking big corporations is both a political message and a policy prescription. It's one way Democrats think they can address the concerns of voters who have fallen behind, even as the U.S. economy continues to expand. As Democrats gear up to try to take back the White House in 2020, they hope the anti-corporate tone taps into the populist passion that propelled Donald Trump in 2016. "Whoever is elected on the Democratic side would be more aggressive on antitrust than we have seen in decades," said Jason Furman, a former chairman of President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers who chairs a U.K. initiative on digital competition. So far, voters views are mixed, but it's a message that could take hold as frustration grows with large companies and concerns, including how personal data are being used. Some of the party's top candidates are warning of a new robber-baron era, recalling the powerful oil and steel behemoths of the late 19th and early 20th centuries that the first American antitrust laws were designed to tame. Their campaigns often cite studies showing that consolidation may be responsible for higher wealth inequality, slower productivity growth, fewer startups and stagnant wages. The candidates are putting together plans to target a wide range of industries including agribusiness, telecom and health care. Booker, for example, has offered legislation that places an indefinite moratorium on acquisitions in the food and agriculture sector and Amy Klobuchar sponsored an antitrust overhaul that would require merging companies to prove their consolidation wouldn't harm competition. The proposals mark a shift from previous administrations that had a lighter regulatory touch, allowing consolidation in almost every sector of the economy. More than three-quarters of U.S. industries over the last two decades have seen an increase in concentration, studies show. Markups - how much a company charges for a product above its own costs - have soared, another sign of rising market power. These findings are consistent with research showing a smaller number of firms across the U.S. economy capturing a greater share of sales, giving rise to so-called superstar companies. Democrats already started questioning this trend after winning the House majority last year. Rep. David Cicilline of Rhode Island, the antitrust subcommittee chairman, is investigating concentration in the tech industry. The U.S., he has said, is in the midst of a "monopoly moment" that stifles competition. One of Cicilline's questions is why there hasn't been a "serious antitrust investigation" in 20 years. At the same time, the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission have carved up oversight of four tech giants, with the Justice Department taking responsibility for Alphabet's Google and Apple, while the FTC is investigating Facebook and Amazon.com. These inquiries could gather steam under a Democratic president, who sets the tone for antitrust enforcement through appointees to the Justice Department and the FTC. A Democratic White House would also likely deploy broader agency regulatory authority to check the power of companies in many industries. That includes the Transportation Department on airlines, the Department of Health and Human Services on insurance and pharmaceutical companies, the Federal Communications Commission on telecom providers, and the Agriculture Department on agribusiness giants.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5ST8-2D01-DY37-30TY-00000-00Horrigan: Big Baby and the triumph of corporate America2018-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. A15Horrigan: Big Baby and the triumph of corporate America By Kevin Horrigan

There's Big Steel. There's Big Pharma. There's Big Tech and Big Coal and Big Banks and Big Oil. Now comes the latest major lobbying organization to throw its weight around and demonstrate the astounding hold that corporate conservatives have on all three branches of the U.S. government.

Say hello to Big Baby.

The New York Times reported last week that during this year's World Health Assembly in May, the U.S. delegation tried to undermine a resolution encouraging women around the world to breastfeed their babies. The assembly is the annual meeting of delegates from 194 nations to the United Nations-affiliated World Health Organization.

For decades, health experts have agreed that mother's milk is better for infants than commercial baby formulas. The resolution urged member countries to regulate the misleading marketing claims of formula manufacturers. The resolution was in no way controversial until the U.S. delegation, representing the interests of Big Baby, started stirring up trouble.

Ecuador, which was scheduled to introduce the resolution, was threatened with trade retaliation and the possible withdrawal of U.S. military aid. Other nations, fearing similar threats, backed down. Eventually the Russians, of all people, agreed to introduce the resolution, and it passed mostly unchanged.

If there's any nation the Trump administration won't mess with, it's Russia.

"We're not trying to be a hero here," a Russian delegate told the Times, "but we feel that it is wrong when a big country tries to push around some very small countries, especially on an issue that is really important for the rest of the world."

This is the sort of thing that U.S. officials used to be able to say. Today they do the bidding of corporate interests. More than three-fourths of the U.S. baby food market is controlled by just three companies: Nestlé USA (Gerber), Abbott Inc. of suburban Chicago (Similac) and Mead Johnson of Chicago (Enfamil). All three are part of Big Baby's $47 billion-a-year global market, which is expected to grow by 50 percent in the next three years no matter what the World Health Assembly says.

With Donald Trump in the White House, Republicans in control of Congress and a corporate majority on the Supreme Court, business has done spectacularly. But trying to convince mothers in the Third World to mix up baby formula - despite having no reliable supply of clean water to mix it with - is truly perverse.

It's the apotheosis for a movement that lay dormant during the years of the New Deal and the Great Society but began to emerge in the 1970s. Movement conservatives appropriated the word "freedom" as a substitute for untrammeled greed. It was truly brilliant how they did it.

They decided that the Gilded Age had it right, and that a nation's greatness should not be measured, as Gandhi said, by how it treats its weakest members, but by how much wealth its strongest members could amass. In support of this, they interpreted the Constitution's insistence on the primacy of property rights as fixed and unchanging.

The key moment came in 1976 when the Supreme Court decided that money, a measure of property, was a protected form of free speech when spent on political contributions. The loudest voices in the public square now belong to those with the most money.

Ronald Reagan became the movement's charismatic figurehead. Social issues like guns, gays and abortion (secondary concerns to most corporate conservatives) were used to divide the old Roosevelt coalition. Dog-whistle racist appeals fomented a backlash to the civil rights movement. Conservative intellectuals - to the extent that sophistic arguments on behalf of the privileged constitutes intellectualism - were planted in universities and courtrooms. Unions, with a big assist from certain corrupt union leaders, became a bad thing - even though collective wealth is the only counterbalance to individual wealth.

The stock market boomed. Executives compensation exploded. Blue-collar wages flatlined. A man named Leonard Leo built an obscure organization of conservative lawyers called the Federalist Society into a powerful force for the protection of corporate interests and wedge social issues. He is chiefly responsible for picking the conservative majority on the Supreme Court - including Brett Kavanaugh, the man Trump nominated last week as Justice Anthony Kennedy's replacement.

"Leonard Leo was a visionary," Tom Carter, who worked as a public relations man for Leo, told The Daily Beast. "He figured out 20 years ago that conservatives had lost the culture war. Abortion, gay rights, contraception - conservatives didn't have a chance if public opinion prevailed. So they needed to stack the courts."

Yes! Public opinion be damned. Just load up the courts with Federalist Society members and wait for the fun to begin. Steal a Supreme Court nomination. Ignore Trump's abuses as long as he supports the plutocratic agenda.

It's like taking candy from a baby. Or worse, mother's milk.

> Kevin Horrigan, a retired member of the Post-Dispatch editorial board, is a St. Louis freelance writer.

5/3/2000 ST. LOUIS: Barbara Wright feeding two of the three infants their formula when they first get up around 7 am. Alec, on left, and Max are pictured, Danielle is being fed by her dad on the couch. PHOTO BY KAREN ELSHOUT/ St. Louis Post-Dispatch Kevin Horrigan, photographed Monday, April 15, 2013.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PJR-K7W1-F0J6-J23M-00000-00Hostility to techs' share classes2017-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:14ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSFinancial TimesPg. 31Hostility to techs' share classesLindsay Fortado, Sujeet Indap and Hannah Kuchler

New York/San Francisco | The tide may be turning against Silicon Valley entrepreneurs who, after floating on the public markets, want to keep a tight grip on their companies through shares with greater voting rights, corporate governance campaigners say.

Growing opposition against founders who want to exert control after listing follows Facebook's decision to scrap a contentious reorganisation of its stock and comes as many of the large private tech groups, from Uber to Airbnb, are expected to go public in the next couple of years.

After shying away from the scrutiny of public markets, some are looking at adopting share structures that give additional voting power to the founder and early investors. But after recent pressure from shareholders, they may now think twice.

Facebook on Friday agreed it would not go through with a share reclassification that would have allowed the founder and controlling shareholder Mark Zuckerberg to sell off stock to fund his philanthropy, while still holding the same voting power. The decision came just days before Mr Zuckerberg was due to testify in a shareholder lawsuit challenging the arrangement.

Facebook's is the latest fight over multiple-class share structures at the biggest US tech companies, which have sparked Wall Street consternation over the protection of shareholder rights. Whereas at most companies one share equals one vote, some of the largest tech groups have created dual share classes to allow their founders to retain a greater percentage of voting rights.

Scott Galloway, a professor of marketing at NYU Stern School of Business and the author of The Four: How Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google Divided and Conquered the World, said the Facebook court case showed it was getting harder for big technology companies to adopt share structures that favoured founders.

"This goes against the general notion that influence should be somewhat correlated to ownership," he said. "But I think the bigger story is the undercurrent has turned against big tech. Lawyers, regulators, politicians and judges are a bit fed up with the prom king who everyone finds charming."

Facebook had followed Alphabet, the parent company of Google that also changed its share structure to ensure its founders retained control.

This had three share classes: one for regular investors with voting power, another for founders with greater voting rights and a third with no vote.

Shareholders sued in that case as well, but settled on the eve of the trial. Alphabet's plan to issue shares with no voting rights went ahead, but the company agreed to compensate investors.

Snap, the owner of Snapchat, went public earlier this year offering shares that gave the most voting power to the two co-founders, prompting S&PDow Jones Indices and FTSE Russell to announce over the northern summer that companies with multiple share classes would not be able to join their indices.

Facebook had sought to reclassify its shares in a similar way to Alphabet by creating a third, non-voting class that it would pay out as a dividend of two for every voting share.

Shareholders had argued it would dilute the value of their shares, and served only to benefit Mr Zuckerberg, who announced in late 2015 he planned to give away 99 per cent of his Facebook stock during his lifetime.

Erik Gordon, an assistant professor at the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business, said the case would influence other leaders looking to adopt similar structures. As large private tech companies such as Uber and Airbnb head to the public markets in the next couple of years, they may reconsider issuing shares with no, or negligible, votes.

Despite the furore surrounding dual or multiple-class companies, they are still a minority among the tech industry's largest groups, amounting to 13 companies out of 128, a study by the law firm Orrick found.

At Snap, prospective investors were told before the company went public that their shares would have no voting power, while co-founders Evan Spiegel and Bobby Murphy would retain shares of the company even if they were no longer executives at the group. Mr Spiegel's voting power would only be lessened if he sold off enough of his stake or died.

Ken Bertsch, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, was disappointed the issue would not now be tested in court. A ruling against the Facebook plan could have prevented other companies who might be considering Alphabet's lead in issuing non-voting shares, he said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X64-7J61-DYTB-V01F-00000-00Hotel industry mounts attack on Airbnb with House bill2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:13ZLexisNexisPg. 14Hotel industry mounts attack on Airbnb with House billBy Alex Gangitano

Airbnb and other short-term rental companies are worried that new legislation in Congress would require them to police their own rental platform and crack down on users.

The fight between the hotel lobby and rental platforms like Airbnb is entering a new phase as lawmakers on Capitol Hill weigh legislation that threatens companies that advertise short-term rentals.

The powerful American Hotel and Lodging Association (AHLA) and tech companies have been facing off in cities and states across the country in recent years, but that battle is now heating up in Washington as lawmakers and regulators weigh a host of measures to address home-sharing services.

In the House, a recently introduced bill would strip online rental websites like Airbnb, HomeAway and Flipkey of federal protections that for years have given internet platforms legal immunity over content posted by third parties.

The Protecting Local Authority and Neighborhoods Act, introduced by Rep. Ed Case (D-Hawaii) on Friday, would make internet platforms liable when they host advertising for short-term rentals that violate state and city laws.

The measure is a top priority for the AHLA, which has spent more than $1.6 million on lobbying this year and has four firms on retainer, including Fierce Government Relations and Peck Madigan Jones.

Association members also pressed lawmakers to back the legislation during the group's annual fly-in on Wednesday.

"For far too long, these Big Tech short-term rental platforms have been hiding behind this antiquated law in order to bully and threaten legal action against local elected officials who are simply trying to protect their residents from illegal rentals that are destroying neighborhoods and access to affordable housing," AHLA President and CEO Chip Rogers said in a statement.

The group has a strong ally in Case, who was senior vice president and chief legal officer at Outrigger Hotels Hawaii from 2013 to 2018 and previously served on the AHLA's board.

In a statement, Case criticized the short-term rental industry, saying it is responsible for "the loss of affordable housing as residential units are converted to transient accommodations for tourists."

"Many of the owners and operators of these units are failing to comply with basic consumer safety, public accommodations and tax requirements that the legal lodging industry has had to follow in order to conduct its business," he added.

Case said that he resigned from the AHLA board in 2017 and has had "no further personal or professional engagements with the visitor industry (other than for representing a district where tourism is the top economic generator and private employer)."

His bill already has bipartisan support. Republican Reps. Pete King (N.Y.) and Ralph Norman (S.C.) are co-sponsors, as is Democratic Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi (Ill.).

The measure now awaits action from the House Energy and Commerce Committee, where Chairman Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J.) and ranking member Greg Walden (R-Ore.) sent a joint letter last month to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer urging him to avoid including language in trade agreements that's similar to the federal third-party protections for internet platforms known as Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act (CDA).

"Sec 230 is meant to enable platforms to take down harmful content. It should not be a shield for inaction," Pallone tweeted in May in response to news of Facebook addressing political disinformation.

The hotel-rental fight over Section 230 comes as the tech industry is facing increased scrutiny in Washington on a number of fronts; lawmakers in both parties have called for revisiting web companies' internet protections.

President Trump signed a bill last year that limits the immunity of Section 230 on platforms that knowingly host content that promotes or assists human trafficking and prostitution. The White House is also reportedly working on an executive order to address anti-conservative bias on the internet that could affect Section 230.

The short-term rental lobby is gearing up for a fight against the bill, pushing back on multiple aspects of its provisions. One of their arguments is that the battle should be at the local level.

The Travel Technology Association, the trade group that represents Expedia, Airbnb, VRBO, Booking.com, Priceline and Trip Advisor, argues that Section 230 is the wrong way to address the issue.

"Amending the CDA for every special interest, such as the hotel lobby, is a flawed approach," Steve Shur, president of the association, told The Hill. "In the context of the broader conversation around Section 230 and legitimate societal challenges, to associate vacation rentals in the same conversation with extremism, illegal gun sales and the opioid crisis is outrageous in its assertion and downright ludicrous to even suggest."

The group said its first step is to educate lawmakers about the legislation.

"The motivations behind this bill are clear ¯ to serve the special interests of the hotel lobby ¯ and Congress shouldn't take the bait," Shur said.

The bill is the latest battle in a long-running fight between the hotel industry and the short-term rental platforms, with hoteliers lobbying for tougher restrictions on businesses like Airbnb in cities and states across the country.

In Washington, the D.C. Council gave preliminary approval to a bill in October that would regulate Airbnb and other short-term rental companies but delayed passage because the measure, introduced by Democratic Councilman Kenyan McDuffie, was predicted to cost the city $104 million over four years. It would impose strict limits on property owners from short-term rentals on second homes, spare bedrooms or basements.

Companies that deal in short-term rentals argue they are working with local governments to address concerns.

"Expedia Group believes in sensible regulation for all segments of the travel ecosystem¯including short-term rentals. We are working closely with cities and states on fair and effective policies that address community concerns, encourage compliance, and support local vacation rental homeowners and managers," Philip Minardi, Expedia Group's director of policy communications, said in a statement.

Expedia owns Hotels.com, Hotwire, Trivago, Orbitz and Travelocity, among other brands, and has spent $560,000 this year on lobbying.

Minardi noted that cities like Seattle and Louisville are implementing policies that work well for both short-term rental companies and the hotel industry.

"Unfortunately, the policy introduced today would jeopardize the important collaboration that's taking place at the state and local level," he said of the Case bill.

In the weeks ahead, Minardi said, Expedia will reach out to policymakers so they "understand the proactive work that is being done to craft fair and effective policies across the nation and the impact that this proposal would have on those efforts."

Shur, of the Travel Technology Association, called the Case bill a "hotel-backed proposal by a former hotel lobbyist turned member of Congress" and a "blatant attempt to do the hotel industry's bidding ... with the hopes of stifling competition from the innovative companies that have helped make short-term rentals and home-sharing popular."

He added that the CDA "maintains a reasonable standard for e-commerce."

Tech companies have long praised Section 230 protections as clearing the way for the growth of the internet.

Steve DelBianco, president of e-commerce trade group NetChoice, which promotes free speech on the internet, called Section 230 "the greatest internet law that no one's ever heard of."

He said issues with short-term rentals should be addressed at the local level.

"Congress should not get involved with how the city of Austin, Texas, enforces its lodging and local zoning laws against property owners," DelBianco said. "But Congress is being pulled into this competitive conflict because Section 230 is a federal law and bars local governments from imposing liability on a platform for commerce and communication that came from users."

Carl Szabo, NetChoice's general counsel, argued that Case's bill would encourage platforms to be less responsive to take down content of bad actors, which is a component of Section 230 and could lead to platforms not doing any moderation at all, similar to how 8chan operates.

"This bill would create disincentives for short term rental platforms to engage in active, aggressive, monitoring of homeowners," he said.

Like others in the short-term rental lobby, DelBianco said NetChoice plans to educate lawmakers "on the general hazards of punching holes in Section 230."
